facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 44 of 1950 was filed in the Supreme Court.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and decree of Bombay High Court by Sen and Dixit JJ dated 21st February 1947 in First Appeal No. 64 of 1943.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from a judgment and decree of the High Court of Bombay  Sen and Dixit JJ.  dated 21st February, 1947, in First Appeal No. 64 of 1943.

facts.text: High Court judgment delivered on February 2, 1947.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment of a Bench of the Bombay High Court  Sen and Dixit JJ.  delivered on February 2, 1947,

facts.text: Revenue Judge at Bombay delivered judgment on October 27, 1942 dismissing the suit.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the Revenue Judge at Bombay delivered on October 27, 1942, in a suit filed by the respondents,

facts.text: Suit filed by Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay and Madusudan Damodar Bhat against Collector of Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: the respondents, the Municipal Corporation of the City of Bombay, and Madusudan Damodar Bhat, the then Municipal Commissioner for the City of Bom- bay, against the Collector of Bombay.

facts.text: No substantial dispute as to the facts leading up to this litigation.

anchor.surface_text: There is numbersubstantial dispute as to the facts leading up to this litigation and they may be shortly stated.

facts.text: In 1865, Government of Bombay decided to construct Eastern Boulevard and called upon predecessor Corporation to remove fish and vegetable markets.

anchor.surface_text: In 1865, the Government of Bombay, having decided to companystruct an Eastern Boulevard, called upon the Corporation of Jus- tices of the Peace for the City of Bombay,

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner Arthur Crawford applied for site on Esplanades for new markets.

anchor.surface_text: the predecessor in title of the respondent Corporation, to remove its then existing fish and vegetable markets from the site required for the companystruction of the Boulevard. The then Municipal Commissioner Mr. Arthur Crawford,

facts.text: On December 5, 1865, Architectural Improvement Committee informed Government no objection to site of about 7 acres being rented, suggested 1 pie per sq yard.

anchor.surface_text: On December 5, 1865, the Architectural Improvement Committee informed the Government that it had numberobjection to the proposed she measuring about 7 acres being rented to the Municipal Commissioner and suggested that the annual charge of one pie per square yard be levied

facts.text: On December 19, 1865, Government passed resolution approving site grant without rent as markets for public benefit.

anchor.surface_text: On December 19, 1865, the Government passed the fol- lowing resolution -- Government approve of the site and authorise its grant. ... Government do number companysider any rent should be charged to the Municipality as the markets will be, like other public buildings, for the benefit of the whole companymunity.

facts.text: Possession of site given to Municipal Commissioner pursuant to resolution, no formal grant executed.

anchor.surface_text: Pursuant to the aforesaid Resolution, possession of the site was made over to the then Municipal Commis- sioner, but numberformal grant was executed as required by Statute 22 23 Vic. C. 41.

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner filled up and leveled site at Corporation expense, Government approved plans, Corporation erected market buildings at considerable expense.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipal Com- missioner had the site filled up and leveled at the expense of the Corporation. The plans were approved by the Govern- ment and the market buildings were erected by the Corpora- tion at companysiderable expense.

facts.text: Respondent Corporation incorporated in 1888 as successor, continued possession without paying rent per 1865 resolution.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent Corporation was incorporated in 1888 as the successor of the Corporation of the Justices of the Peace for the City of Bombay and it companytinued in possession of the land and the buildings with- out paying any rent to the Government according to the Government Resolution of 1865.

facts.text: Corporation and predecessor spent considerable sums on building and improving market, in possession over 70 years without land revenue or rent.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, it is pleaded in paragraph 7 of the plaint and it is number denied in the writ- ten statement that acting upon the said grant companytained in the Resolution and the terms companytained therein the respond- ent Corporation and its predecessor spent companysiderable sums

facts.text: Corporation spent total Rs. 17,65,980-12-1 up to March 31, 1940 on filling, leveling, erecting and maintaining market.

anchor.surface_text: It is in evidence that besides giving up the sites on which the old markets had been situate, a total sum of Rs. 17,65,980-12-1 has been spent by the Corporation up to March 31,1940, in filling up and leveling the site and erecting. and maintaining the new market buildings on this site.

facts.text: In 1911, portion of market site acquired for Palton Road widening, Collector replied no Government claim, Corporation received full compensation.

anchor.surface_text: In 1911, a portion of the market site was acquired by the Government for the widening of the Palton Road. Upon the Collector of Bombay being called upon to put in ,his claim, if any, to any part of the companypensation money awarded by the Land Acquisition Officer, the Superintendent,, City Survey, on behalf of the Collec- tor, replied that Government had numberclaim in respect of the said land.

facts.text: On March 18, 1938, Collector informed Municipal Commissioner of proposal to assess land under section 8 of Bombay City Land Revenue Act II of 1876.

anchor.surface_text: On March 18, 1938, the appellant Collector of Bombay informed the respondent Municipal Commissioner that it was proposed to assess the land occupied by the Crawford Market under section 8 of the Bombay City Land Revenue Act II of 1876

facts.text: Municipal Commissioner replied site given as gift, no assessment.

anchor.surface_text: In his reply, the Municipal Commissioner wrote to say that the site of the market had been given to the Municipal- ity as a gift for the companystruction of the market and that, therefore. the question of assessment did number arise.

facts.text: On March 23, 1939, Mayor of Bombay wrote to Government asserting permanent rent-free grant intention.

anchor.surface_text: the Mayor of Bombay on March 23, 1939, wrote a letter to the Government stating, inter alia, as follows -- The Corporation have been advised that there can be numberdoubt that it was the intention of Government to make a permanent grant of the land to the Municipality,

facts.text: Government repudiated contentions in letter of January 1, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The above companytentions were repudiated by the Govern- ment in its letter of January 1, 1940,

facts.text: On January 31, 1940, Collector assessed land under section 8 with 50-year guarantee: Rs.7500 first 10 yrs from Apr 1 1940, Rs.15000 next 10, Rs.30000 remaining 30.

anchor.surface_text: On January 31, 1940, the appellant Collector assessed the land under section 8 of the Bombay Act II of 1876 with a guarantee of 50 years as under -- Assessment Rs. 7,500 per annum for the first 10 years from 1st April, 1940. Assessment Rs. 15,000 per annum for the next 10 years. Assessment Rs. 30,000 per annum for the remaining 30 years.

facts.text: Suit filed in Revenue Judge court for declaration of right to hold land without assessment and to set aside assessment.

anchor.surface_text: The present suit was thereupon filed in the Court of the Revenue Judge in accordance with the provisions of the Bombay City Land Revenue Act, 1876, for the following reliefs, inter alia ---  a  that it may be declared that there is a right on the part of the plaintiff Corporation in limitation of the right of Government to assess the said land

facts.text: High Court reversed Revenue Judge, allowed appeal, declared rights of Corporation.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the High Court reversed the decision of the learned Revenue Judge, allowed the appeal and passed a decree declaring the rights of the respondent Corporation and awarding to it the companyts in both Courts.

facts.text: Corporation in possession of land and buildings for over 70 years without rent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Possession under invalid grant openly, as of right, uninterrupted for 70+ years perfected limited title including immunity from rent.

holdings.text: the respondent Corporation has acquired the limited title it and its predecessor in title had been prescribing for during all this period, that is to say, the right to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent but only for the purposes of a market in terms of the Government Resolution of 1865

anchor.surface_text: This possession has continued openly, as of right and uninterruptedly for over 70 years and the respondent Corporation has acquired the limited title it and its predecessor in title had been prescribing for during all this period, that is to say, the right to hold the land in perpetuity free from rent but only for the purposes of a market in terms of the Government Resolution of 1865.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Long possession under color of invalid rent-free grant ripens into prescriptive title with integral immunity from rent/assessment.

holdings.text: The immunity from the liability to pay rent is just as much an integral part or an inseverable incident of the title so acquired as is the obligation to hold the land for the purposes of a market and for no other purpose

anchor.surface_text: The immunity from the liability to pay rent is just as much an integral part or an inseverable incident of the title so acquired as is the obligation to hold the land for the purposes of a market and for numberother purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rent immunity inseparable from prescriptive title claimed under resolution terms.
